awd_abstract_narration:
This award continues the research program of eight faculty members and their students in Nuclear Structure Physics and Nuclear Astrophysics at the University of Notre Dame.   The program focuses on direct measurements of nuclear reaction and decay processes that determine the life of stars and the origin of the elements in the universe. This program addresses key nuclear processes that define the timescales of stellar evolution and explosion processes.  Another component is the study of low energy fusion reactions during the last days of a stellar life prior to supernova explosion. The program also explores the nuclear structure effects and weak interaction processes that are guiding large scale nucleosynthesis processes. The research is performed primarily by using the accelerators of the Nuclear Science Laboratory (NSL) at the University of Notre Dame, which are uniquely designed to probe stellar reactions through a number of experimental techniques. The experimental results expand our knowledge of the fundamental structure of the nucleus as a multi-body quantum system; they also provide new insight for the astrophysics community on the origin of the elements and the chemical evolution of the cosmos from the Big Bang to the present.  The NSL is uniquely equipped for performing this kind of research in a university environment.  The award will support the training of a large number of graduate (approximately 30) and undergraduate students (approximately 20) in experimental and theoretical techniques to be ready to join the nuclear workforce of the nation. 

The experimental program is based on the use of two accelerators at the NSL. Intense stable ion beams from the single ended 5U Pelletron are used for the direct study of low-energy capture and fusion reactions. Heavy ion beams are used to investigate such reactions in inverse kinematic technique using the St. GEORGE recoil separator. This separator is unique and serves as blueprint for the design of the SECAR separator at FRIB. The FN tandem accelerator is used as a multi-purpose instrument. It is operated as a driver for the production of radioactive beams at the TwinSol facility, the nationss first instrument for producing low energy radioactive beams. These beams allow direct reaction measurements with and the trapping of light radioactive particles at levels not possible at large national facilities. The FN also serves the accelerator mass spectrometry (AMS) program at the NSL, testing geological and cosmological samples for long-lived radioactivities.  A large number of nuclear structure experiments is based on the operation of this machine using a variety of particle and gamma spectroscopy techniques.  A smaller fraction of the program relies on the use of other national and international facilities to take advantage of higher energy beams not available at the NSL.

por.por_cntn:
Research at the Nuclear Science Laboratory (NSL) at Notre Dame covers three major areas in low energy nuclear physics, nuclear astrophysics, the structure of the nucleus, and nuclear applications. Relevant questions in these three disciplines are attacked and answered using a broad portfolio if instrumentation at the NSL as well as at other nuclear physics laboratories worldwide.

Nuclear Astrophysics

For nuclear astrophysics the NSL researchers have followed a multifaceted experimental program coupled with theoretical predictions and simulations of reaction and nucleosynthesis processes.

We have studied the most important nuclear reactions producing the energy and neutrinos in our sun. Also investigated were reactions that lead to the production of carbon and oxygen as the fundamental building blocks for life. Several potential neutron sources for different s-process environments in stars such as, 13C(α,n), 17O,18O(α,n), and 25Mg(α,n) have been studied, to investigate the temperature dependence of neutron production and the impact on s-process nucleosynthesis at these burning conditions. We also expanded on the low energy study of the 12C+12C fusion reaction. The prediction of molecular cluster resonances in the system is confirmed and new models for extrapolating the experimental data into the stellar energy range.  

Critical reactions that define the onset of stellar explosions from novae, X-Ray bursts to supernovae have been investigated. A number of reactions important for mapping the time structure of x-ray bursts and the subsequent cooling phase in x-ray burst transients have been performed at Notre Dame and the NSCL.

The r-process in neutron star mergers is considered to be the origins of many of the heavy elements beyond Iron. A number of experiments at Jyv?skyl? and ANL have been performed to study critical masses and lifetimes of nuclei far off stability at and near the r-process path to provide a more detailed map of the r-process path for reliably interpret nucleosynthesis pattern in the merger event.

An important aspect of core collapse supernovae is the incompressibility of nuclear matter which drives the bounce and triggers the initial supernova shock traversing infalling material. The study of nuclear oscillations provides an important tool for directly measuring nuclear matter features such as incompressibility, which is also important for the understanding of the equation of state of the remaining neutron star matter.

The AMS program at the NSL focuses the analysis of long-lived radioactivities with applications to galactic radio-activities and cosmochronology. Recent new detection capabilities have greatly enhanced the current program providing insight into early solar system production of Short-Lived Radionuclide.

Nuclear Structure and Fundamental Symmetry

The vibrational and rotational character of exciting a given nucleus yield information about the quantum mechanics of the atom. Several studies of deformed nuclei and the lifetimes of their excited states have been studied. The final picture yields a much better understanding of the degrees of freedom in deformed prolate shaped nuclei.

In light mass nuclei, we can unravel the complex working of the internucleon interactions with calculations starting  with ab-initio nuclear model calculations. The new fIREBall array has been directed to the studies of crucial  transitions in light nuclei.

The fundamental symmetry program focusing on testing the standard model using superallowed mixed beta decay transitions between mirror nuclei has been growing with the most precise half-life measurements to date of several such isotope as well as the development of the St. Benedict ion trapping system.

Nuclear Applications

Nuclear applications are part of the broader impact effort of the NSL. This includes critical experiments for fusion environments such as the NIF or the Boron Reactor. They also cover questions of long term storage of radioactive waste, the investigation of archaeological materials, and the production of medical isotopes.  

Nuclear Instrumentation

For all these efforts a broad portfolio of novel instrumentation has been developed. A unique tool is the St. George recoil separator which now serves as blue-print for the much larger SECAR separator at the NSCL. The local experiments are complemented by studies at the recently installed CASPAR accelerator 1 mile underground at Homestake Mine in South Dakota.  

The TwinSol system was upgraded by adding a third solenoid component, to provide a much broader range of radioactive beams. This improvement stimulated a considerably broader research program in nuclear astrophysics and fundamental symmetries for local NSL researchers as well as outside users at TriSol.

New tools and techniques have been developed. This includes the HECTOR summing detector for radiative capture studies, the SAND detector for particle gamma coincidence measurements for low energy fusion reactions, and the ND-Cube for investigating  halo nuclei and pycnonuclear reactions. The fIREBall array has been successfully implemented for the measurement of conversion electrons following nuclear reactions. Finally, considerable effort was invested in the development and optimization of the ODeSA detector and the implementation of 3He-spectrometer for the measurement of (α,n) reactions and the characterization of neutron beamsat the NSL.
